item.title: Facing Global Outrage, Netanyahu Calls Civilian Deaths in Rafah Strike ‘Tragic Accident’
item.description: The strike on Sunday, which Israeli officials said targeted two Hamas leaders taking cover near a civilian encampment, ignited a fire that killed 45 people, according to the Gazan authorities.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Palestinians on Monday inspected damage after an Israeli strike near a camp for displaced people in Rafah set off a fire that killed at least 45 people.

item.title: Papua New Guinea Landslide Has Buried 2,000 People, Officials Say
item.description: Just getting to survivors has proved to be an enormous challenge, with a blocked highway and unstable ground “posing ongoing danger” to rescue workers.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The aftermath of a landslide in Enga Province, Papua New Guinea, on Sunday.

item.title: North Korea Launches Long-Range Rocket Carrying Satellite
item.description: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, has made deploying a fleet of spy satellites one of his country’s latest ​military ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Watching a news broadcast of North Korea’s rocket launch in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Amid Condemnation, Netanyahu Calls Civilian Deaths in Rafah Strike ‘Tragic Accident’
item.description: The Israeli leader’s comments came at a particularly delicate time, just days after the International Court of Justice appeared to order Israel to immediately halt its offensive in the city.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Lawmakers Visit Taiwan and Vow Support in Face of Chinese Military Drills
item.description: A bipartisan delegation promised to stand by the island’s newly elected president, Lai Ching-te, after Beijing surrounded the self-governing island with naval vessels and aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Taiwan Presidential office, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan, right, with Representative Michael McCaul, Republican of Texas, in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday.

item.title: This Island Wants to Round Up Its Wild Goats. Catching Them Won’t Be Easy.
item.description: The ruminants outnumber humans on the Mediterranean island of Alicudi 6 to 1 (maybe more). Officials have devised a plan to catch the goats and send them to adoptive homes elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

item.title: Onstage, Witches and Cossacks Strike a Chord With Ukrainians
item.description: A play based on an 19th-century literary classic is a smash hit among Ukrainians who see in the story cultural and historical echoes of what they face after two years of war.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Witch of Konotop,” at the Ivan Franko theater in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Putin Shakes Up Things at Home as His Optimism About Ukraine War Rises
item.description: Despite years of criticism, President Vladimir V. Putin has only now changed his defense minister and allowed high-level corruption arrests.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A military parade this month in Moscow.

item.title: China, Japan and South Korea Hold Talks Overshadowed by U.S.
item.description: In the first trilateral meeting since 2019, the neighbors sought common ground in trade and cultural exchange while tiptoeing around thorny security issues.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea, center, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan, left, and Chinese Premier Li Qiang at a joint news conference in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: Spying Arrests Send Chill Through Britain’s Thriving Hong Kong Community
item.description: Tens of thousands of Hong Kongers have resettled in the U.K. since 2021, among them prominent pro-democracy activists. China has not forgotten them.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Simon Cheng, an activist from Hong Kong now living in Britain, last week in the offices of Hongkongers in London. The painting behind him depicts protesters in Hong Kong carrying their iconic yellow umbrellas.

item.title: Amateur Historians Heard Tales of a Lost Tudor Palace. Then, They Dug It Up.
item.description: In a small English village, a group of dedicated locals has unearthed the remains of a long-vanished palace that had been home to Henry VIII’s grandmother.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chris Close, center left, in green jacket, consulting with Jennifer Browning, an archaeologist, during work on the dig site in Collyweston, England, early this year.

item.title: The Deadly Prelude to South Africa’s First Free Elections
item.description: The vote in 1994 was a time of hope — but in the weeks before, the country came close to the abyss. A photographer remembers what he witnessed.
item.dc:creator: Joao Silva

item.title: Free Food? Modi Makes Sure Every Indian Knows Whom to Thank for It.
item.description: India’s welfare programs improve lives. Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party uses its vast machinery to ensure the handouts also create loyal voters.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vinod Misra, a local Bharatiya Janata Party official, talking with a potter in Amethi, India, who received an electric potter’s wheel through a government program.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: We’re covering Israel’s offensive in Rafah and the death toll from the Papua New Guinea landslide.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: The destruction after an Israeli strike on a camp for displaced people in Rafah.

item.title: South Africa’s Young Democracy Leaves Its Young Voters Disillusioned
item.description: We spoke to South Africans who grew up in the three decades since the country overthrew apartheid and held its first free election about their lives and plans to vote — or not — in this week's pivotal election.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Joao Silva

item.title: Leaflet by Leaflet, a Few Aging Activists Fight India’s Tide of Bigotry
item.description: As politicians stoke religious hatred online, these veterans of social causes deliver their messages in person: “Talk to each other. Don’t let anyone divide you.”
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roop Rekha Verma, 80, talking to women at a home in Lucknow, India, about their right to vote.

item.title: Shooting Near Rafah Border Crossing Kills a Member of Egypt’s Security Forces
item.description: The Israeli military also reported a shooting at the border, where it is fighting Palestinian militants.
item.dc:creator: Emad Mekay and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Macron says Israeli operations in Rafah ‘must stop,’ and more news.
Inside the Factory Supplying Half of Africa’s Syringes
item.description: In Kenya, Revital Healthcare is manufacturing medical products that Africa needs to take charge of routine health care and respond to outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Brian Otieno
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: We’re covering a Ukrainian warning of a new Russian offensive as well as a Hamas strike on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hardware superstore was hit in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: 12 Injured on Qatar Airways Flight From Turbulence
item.description: The Dublin Airport said that a Qatar Airways flight from Doha landed in Ireland after a dozen people were injured by turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Qatar Airways flight QR017 was flying over Turkey when turbulence injured a dozen passengers.

item.title: Deadly Fires Highlight India’s Safety Shortfall
item.description: Disasters over the weekend that claimed at least 34 lives prompted condolences, arrests and finger-pointing. But systemic change remains elusive, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Pragati K.B. and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Damaged buildings on Sunday after a fire in an amusement park that killed at least 27 people in Rajkot, India.

item.title: Russia Plans New Ukraine Offensive as Zelensky Urges Biden and Xi to Join Peace Summit
item.description: Moscow is again amassing forces near the border, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine warned. His comments came as officials said that a Russian strike had killed at least 16 people in Kharkiv.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers at a hardware superstore that was hit by a Russian strike, according to Ukrainian officials, on Sunday in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Death Toll in Papua New Guinea Landslide Estimated to Be at Least 670
item.description: More than 48 hours after the disaster, its full extent remains unclear, with aid slow to reach survivors and conditions on the ground still dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Mohamud Omer/International Organization for Migration, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Villagers searching in the aftermath of a landslide in Yambali, Papua New Guinea, on Sunday.

item.title: Aid Deliveries From Egypt Into Gaza Resume
item.description: Under a U.S.-brokered agreement, Egypt allowed trucks to pass through the Israeli-controlled Kerem Shalom.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: Egyptian trucks carrying humanitarian aid bound for the Gaza Strip waiting on the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing on Sunday.

item.title: Peru’s New Rule on Transgender Health Care Draws Backlash
item.description: Government officials say the regulation was intended to expand mental health care access for transgender people. Activists say it will increase discrimination.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Mitra Taj
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Police officers guarding the entrance of the Ministry of Health during a protest this month in Lima, Peru, that was staged by L.G.B.T.Q. groups against a new government decree listing transgender identity as a “mental disorder.”

item.title: The Hamas Chief and the Israeli Who Saved His Life
item.description: In an Israeli prison infirmary, a Jewish dentist came to the aid of a desperately ill Hamas inmate. Years later, the prisoner became a mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack.
item.dc:creator: Jo Becker and Adam Sella

item.title: Why Do Aid Groups Stay in Lawless Haiti?
item.description: Two American missionaries and a Haitian aid director were killed, the latest gang violence against aid groups in Haiti’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Gangs control about 90 percent of Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, leaving much of the population of six million unable to move freely.

item.title: Russia Strikes Hardware Store in Kharkiv, Killing 12, Ukraine Says
item.description: It was the latest attack in a sustained bombing campaign that has made life increasingly dangerous for civilians in the northeastern Ukrainian city.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A shopping mall in Kharkiv was hit with two powerful aerial bombs in the middle of the day on Saturday, one of several strikes against the city.

item.title: Deadly Fire in India Amusement Leaves at Least 27 Dead, Police Say
item.description: Officers said the cause of the fire was still under investigation, but that they planned to charge the owner of the facility with negligence.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Firefighters at the scene of a deadly fire at an amusement park in Rajkot, in western India, on Saturday.

item.title: Some U.S. Weapons Stymied by Russian Jamming in Ukraine
item.description: Two classified Ukrainian reports show that some U.S. precision-guided weapons are vulnerable to electronic warfare, an element in Ukraine’s recent battlefield setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Vladyslav Golovin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery crew firing at Russian positions in the northern Kharkiv region. Ukraine has provided a testing ground for weapons not previously used against a high-tech enemy like Russia.

item.title: 5 Mount Everest Climbers Are Dead and 3 Missing This Summit Season
item.description: Unnerving videos have circulated, showing a snarl of climbers on the summit ridge even as fewer permits were issued this year. Eighteen climbers died in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Tsering Pemba Sherpa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mountaineers at the Khumbu Glacier this month making their way to Mount Everest’s summit in Nepal.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Could Restart Cease-Fire Talks Within a Week, Officials Say
item.description: Negotiators held preliminary discussions in Paris this weekend, hoping to revive the possibility of a truce, the officials said.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynoldsgil Cohen-Magenfabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The C.I.A. director, William Burns; Israel’s Mossad director, David Barnea; and Qatar’s prime minister, Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani.

item.title: Mohammad Rasoulof, Director Who Fled Iran, Brings a Message of Hope to Cannes
item.description: At a news conference for his film “The Seed of the Sacred Fig,” Mohammad Rasoulof reveled details of his escape from the country to avoid a prison sentence.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: The Seed of the Sacred Fig (Movie)
item.media:description: Mohammad Rasoulof, center, with the actresses Setareh Maleki and Mahsa Rostami at a news conference for the film “The Seed of the Sacred Fig” in Cannes, France, on Saturday.

item.title: Crowds for Raisi Show Support for Iranian State, Supreme Leader Says
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei pointed to the turnout at memorials for Iran’s president at a time when external critics say popular backing for the Islamic Republic has weakened.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians attending a funeral ceremony for President Ebrahim Raisi in Tehran on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Steps Up Attacks With U.S. Long-Range Missiles
item.description: The assaults have hit military targets in Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine. Pressure is now mounting on Washington to let Kyiv fire the missiles into Russia itself.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Military investigators working on the site of a strike in Donetsk, in Russian-controlled Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Israel Continues Military Offensive in Rafah After ICJ Order
item.description: The court on Friday ordered Israel to suspend its military offensive and “any other action” in Rafah that might wholly or partly destroy the Palestinian population there.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley

item.title: African Music to the World
item.description: Artists from the continent are breaking into the Western mainstream. We’ve got a playlist for your weekend cookout.
item.dc:creator: Desiree Ibekwe

item.title: After Billions of Dollars in Losses, Canada Post Warns It May Run Out of Cash
item.description: While the post office considers plans to revamp its business model, any major fixes are likely to be politically vexing.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: In its 2023 annual report, Canada Post warned that its financial situation was “unsustainable.”

item.title: For This Ukrainian Town, Drones Have Offered Last Line of Defense Against Russia
item.description: Short of troops and artillery, soldiers increasingly have been relying on pilotless drones to drop explosives and supplies to hold Chasiv Yar. But how long can they slow the Russian advance?
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the 92nd Assault Brigade testing a Vampire drone in a field in the Donetsk region of Ukraine this month.

item.title: Condemnation Slows, but Does Not Stall, Israel’s Assault on Rafah
item.description: Despite fierce criticism, Israel insists it must take control of Rafah and the border with Egypt to prevent future arms smuggling.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Isabel Kershner and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: A camp, once overwhelmed by displaced people from around Gaza and now mostly deserted, on Wednesday in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: 17 Hours to Find the Crash That Killed Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s President
item.description: As a frenzied quest began for the fallen helicopter of President Ebrahim Raisi, Iran moved to control possible threats from abroad and unrest at home.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Azin Haghighi/MOJ News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers on Monday with a body from the fallen helicopter that was carrying President Ebrahim Raisi in northwestern Iran.

item.title: Why Are So Many Mexican Election Candidates Getting Killed?
item.description: Across Mexico, dozens of candidates, their relatives and party members have been targeted in violent attacks before next month’s general election.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: A municipal police officer stands guard in Maravatio, Mexico, in February.

item.title: One of the Deadliest Jobs in Mexico: Running for Office
item.description: The assassination of Gisela Gaytán shocked Mexico. She was among dozens of aspirants for public office killed in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
item.media:description: Relatives of Gisela Gaytán mourning during her funeral in Celaya, Mexico, on April 3.

item.title: Hundreds Feared Dead in Papua New Guinea Landslide
item.description: Nearly 4,000 people live in villages that were engulfed, a local official said. Unstable debris was complicating search and rescue efforts in a rural part of the Pacific nation.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Christopher Cottrell
item.media:description: A huge landslide in Papua New Guinea’s Enga Province on Friday engulfed three villages.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Recipe for Total Control: An Army of Eyes and Ears
item.description: Reviving a Mao-era surveillance campaign, the authorities are tracking residents, schoolchildren and businesses to forestall any potential unrest.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers from a neighborhood committee keeping watch on a Beijing street in April. “Stability maintenance” — a catchall term for containing social problems and silencing dissent — has increasingly become a preoccupation in China under Xi Jinping.

item.title: Sometimes U.S. and U.K. Politics Seem in Lock Step. Not This Year.
item.description: In 2016, Britain voted for Brexit and America for Trump, heralding a populist wave. Both countries face pivotal elections this year — but their paths appear to have diverged.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The British Parliament will stop sitting next week, with an election coming on July 4.

item.title: ICJ Orders Israel to Halt Its Military Incursion Into Rafah
item.description: The International Court of Justice has no means to enforce its order in the Gazan city, but the ruling added pressure on the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta, Aaron Boxerman and Yonette Joseph
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Smoke rising after an Israeli airstrike in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Friday.

item.title: Are These Drones Too Chinese to Pass U.S. Muster in an Anti-China Moment?
item.description: U.S.-based Anzu Robotics is selling drones using technology from DJI, a Chinese firm that is the target of efforts by lawmakers to limit Chinese technology in America.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Randall Warnas, chief executive of Anzu Robotics, with a Raptor drone outside a warehouse in Lindon, Utah, earlier this month.

item.title: Top U.N. Court Decision Adds to Israel’s Growing Isolation
item.description: An order to stop the Rafah offensive was the latest action against Israel, all of which create “a tremendous sense of pressure,” a former consul general said.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A decision by the International Court of Justice highlighted Israel’s growing diplomatic isolation.

item.title: Israeli Forces Cut Off Access to Kamal Adwan Hospital in Northern Gaza
item.description: Israeli bombardments and raids have put many of Gaza’s hospitals out of operation and only a few remain even partially functional.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: People evacuating Kamal Adwan Hospital following an Israeli strike in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Countries Fail to Agree on Treaty to Prepare the World for the Next Pandemic
item.description: Negotiators plan to ask for more time. Among the sticking points are equitable access to vaccines and financing to set up surveillance systems.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Last year’s World Health Assembly in Geneva. Member countries have failed to reach their goal of finalizing a pandemic treaty before this year’s session begins on Monday.

item.title: Taquería El Califa de León Went From Local Favorite to World Famous
item.description: Taquería El Califa de León, in Mexico City, became the first Mexican taco stand to win a Michelin star. Since then, it has been deluged with customers and fame.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas
item.category: Taqueria El Califa de Leon (Mexico City, Mexico, Restaurant)
item.media:description: Arturo Rivera Martínez has been behind the grill at El Califa de León for 20 years.

item.title: Three Missionaries in Haiti Killed in Gang Attack
item.description: The latest assault by Haitian gangs left three people, including two American missionaries and a local pastor, dead in Port-au-Prince.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:description: Haiti has been in the throes of a massive gang assault since last February, when several gangs that normally fight each other decided to band together and fight the government.

item.title: Why We Should Have Nice Things
item.description: Modern soccer shouldn’t be set up to rob fans of their joy.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Bayer Leverkusen’s defeat in the Europa League final spoiled a night. It shouldn’t spoil an unforgettable season.

item.title: Milk Containing Bird-Flu Virus Can Sicken Mice, Study Finds
item.description: The results bolster evidence that virus-laden raw milk may be unsafe for humans.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Bottles of raw milk are displayed for sale at a store in Temecula, Calif.

item.title: Kabosu, Shiba Inu Dog Who Helped Define the Doge Meme, Dies at 18
item.description: The dog, whose face helped spread the popular doge meme and later became the logo of the Dogecoin cryptocurrency, died on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Ms. Sato decorated her home with photos of Kabosu.

item.title: Landslide Buries Village in Papua New Guinea, Killing at Least 3
item.description: Many more were missing in the Pacific nation as recovery and rescue efforts were delayed by a blocked highway and fallen boulders.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: The site of a landslide in Papua New Guinea’s Enga Province on Friday.
